active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the trade-offs between relying on VPNs for MITM protection on public WiFi versus implementing app-level measures like certificate pinning and HSTS. Consider usability, performance, and coverage for sensitive mobile app data. Support arguments with real-world examples like Heartbleed or public hotspot attacks.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) Attack Prevention (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > 008_Application Security > Mobile 008_Application Security > 005_Network Communication Security > Network Attack Prevention > Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) Attack Prevention). Generate 50 high-quality Anki-style flashcards optimized for spaced repetition, active recall, and Bloom's Taxonomy progression. Incorporate: - Learning Objectives: [insert full list above] - Prior Knowledge: Network interception basics, TLS fundamentals. - Scaffolding Layers: [insert full descriptions above]. Distribute cards: 30% Layer 1-2, 40% Layer 3, 30% Layer 4. - Active Learning Tie-Ins: Reference discussions, peer teaching, problem-solving in explanations. - Best Practices (Complete): Strict certificate validation (full chain, revocation checks), HSTS (preload, max-age), certificate pinning (public key), TLS 1.3 min, disable weak ciphers, VPN for mobile, user education, avoid HTTP. - Research: NIST SP 800-52r2, OWASP TLS Cheat Sheet, phases (interception/decryption/forwarding), examples (public WiFi, Heartbleed). - Big Picture: Layered mobile app defense for sensitive data, PCI DSS compliance. Follow Flashcard Schema exactly: - 40% Cloze/Short Answer, 60% MCQ. - Front: Engaging question. - Back: Answer | Explanation (pedagogy links) | MCQ Options (A/B/C/D, bold correct) | References. - Distractors: 3 plausible per MCQ protocol. - Ensure university pedagogy: Scaffold from remember to create, voter-approved completeness (68.6% consensus). Output as JSON array: [{'front': '...', 'back': '...'}, ...]. No extras.
